author: Abby Heugel
title: Driver Licenses From These States Soon Won’t Be Valid IDs For Domestic Flights
text:
Over 3 million people just like you 'Like' us » Like it? Share it! 176 Shares 
Are you planning on traveling any time soon? If you are — and you're from one nine states — you better have something other than a driver's license as a form of ID. 
Residents of Kentucky, Maine, Minnesota, Missouri, Montana, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, and Washington will have to use alternate ID forms (passport, military ID, or permanent resident card) to pass TSA security checkpoints — even for domestic travel. The TSA has started placing signage around airport security checkpoints to inform travelers of the new TSA rules going into effect in 2018. 
Why the switch? 
The IDs from these nine states do not meet the federal government’s minimum security standards. And, according to the REAL ID Act of 2005, federal agencies (like the TSA) are prohibited from “accepting for certain purposes driver’s licenses and identification cards from states not meeting the Act’s minimum standards.” The TSA said in a statement that if the nine states change their ID process, the government “may grant extensions or determine compliance for additional states as warranted." 
As for travelers who are not from the nine states, they won’t be affected by the change in 2018. But by 2020, all travelers must have identification in compliance with REAL ID or they will not be allowed through TSA security checkpoints. 
(And we know how stressful that can be already.) Only twenty-four states (plus Washington, D.C.) currently comply with the rules set forward in the act. 
The remaining states have been given extensions through 2017 to meet REAL ID standards. 
So what should you do if you’re from one of those nine states and planning on traveling soon? 
You can either get a passport or wait and see if your state’s laws change in time to comply with the TSA. And the TSA added that they will update signage if and when states that are currently listed receive extensions. 
Better safe than sorry!
